So the Earth takes 365.25 days to orbit the Sun once. That means it orbits the Sun approximately every 365 days, but with a quarter day extra each year. Over four years, that extra quarter day adds up to an extra day, which is why we have leap years every four years.

Now, the question is asking how many times the Earth orbits the Sun in 50 years, considering leap years. So, first, I need to figure out how many leap years there are in 50 years.

Normally, a leap year occurs every 4 years. So, in 50 years, the number of leap years would be 50 divided by 4, which is 12.5. But since we can't have half a leap year, we need to see if 50 years include 12 or 13 leap years.

To be precise, leap years are years that are divisible by 4, but there are exceptions. For example, years that are divisible by 100 are not leap years unless they are also divisible by 400. So, for a 50-year period, these exceptions might or might not apply, depending on which years are included.
